revised_title: Trypanosomes in Wild Animals and Their Role in Sleeping Sickness
tldr: The authors conducted a study on the prevalence of trypanosomes in wild animals living in the sleeping-sickness area of Nyasaland. They found that 31.7% of the animals tested positive for pathogenic trypanosomes, with the most common species being Trypanosoma brucei vel rhodesiense. The authors recommend controlling the population of these wild animals in the fly-infested areas to prevent the spread of the disease to humans and domestic animals.
